G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A.proposition: This action is brought in the Chelsea Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 212, § 3, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Chelsea, Massachusetts, and the Property is located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This action is brought in the Chelsea Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 212, § 3, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Chelsea, Massachusetts, and the Property is located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: Defendant John Ramirez is, on information and belief, an individual residing in Massachusetts who is the owner and/or manager of the residential rental property located at 45 Broadway Street, Chelsea, Massachusetts 02150 (the “Property”), and Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, residential tenants are entitled to the covenant of quiet enjoyment, implied in every lease and tenancy, and expressly protected by G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 15F.proposition: The defective condition of the Main Entry Door lock constitutes a failure to provide reasonable security for the building and its occupants and is a violation of the landlord’s duty to maintain common areas in a reasonably safe condition.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: The defective condition of the Main Entry Door lock constitutes a failure to provide reasonable security for the building and its occupants and is a violation of the landlord’s duty to maintain common areas in a reasonably safe condition.

105 C.M.R. 410.480, 410.750..proposition: The defective condition of the Main Entry Door lock constitutes a failure to provide reasonable security for the building and its occupants and is a violation of the landlord’s duty to maintain common areas in a reasonably safe condition.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: Massachusetts law and regulations require residential premises to be kept in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, including requirements for safe and secure egress and building security.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 15.proposition: Landlords have a duty to maintain common areas, including entrance doors and locks, in a condition that is reasonably safe and secure for tenants.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, residential tenants are entitled to the covenant of quiet enjoyment, implied in every lease and tenancy, and expressly protected by G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts and explains that every tenancy includes an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. It also interprets and applies G.L. c. 186, § 14, which statutorily protects tenants against interference with quiet enjoyment and provides damages and attorney’s fees. Together, these passages affirm that Massachusetts residential tenants are entitled both to the implied covenant and to its statutory protection under § 14.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.” (385 Mass. at 102–03).

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, residential tenants are entitled to the covenant of quiet enjoyment, implied in every lease and tenancy, and expressly protected by G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and explicitly describes G.L. c. 186, § 14 as the ‘quiet enjoyment’ statute protecting residential tenants. While the excerpt does not restate that the covenant is ‘implied in every lease and tenancy,’ that point is well-established in Massachusetts law and is assumed in the court’s discussion that tenants may sue their landlord under § 14 for interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case supports the proposition that Massachusetts residential tenants are entitled to the covenant of quiet enjoyment and that it is expressly protected by G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “3. Covenant of quiet enjoyment. The plaintiffs argue that the judge erred in granting summary judgment in favor of the defendant on their claim that the defendant violated G. L. c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), the so-called ‘quiet enjoyment’ statute. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 94 (1982). … General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from serious, substantial, or unreasonable interference with the use and enjoyment of their premises that is the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts or omissions.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that a breach occurs where serious interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment is the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts, omissions, or permissions, regardless of the landlord’s subjective intent. The court affirms liability where tenants were “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment by noise that was the foreseeable result of the landlord leasing to and permitting operation of the lounge and failing effectively to abate it.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent…”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 851\u.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises and common areas in a reasonably safe and secure condition can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where it substantially interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 851\u.support_reasoning: The case squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and explains that a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known defects or unsafe conditions in leased premises can violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the natural and probable consequence is interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment. Although the facts involve lead paint, the Court relies on and reaffirms earlier cases (Simon, Darmetko, Dorgan, Cruz) holding that failure to repair known defects in the premises and common areas can constitute a § 14 breach, which matches the proposition stated.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 851\u.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 167\u2.proposition: Landlords have a duty to maintain common areas, including entrance doors and locks, in a condition that is reasonably safe and secure for tenants.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 167\u2.support_reasoning: The case directly discusses a landlord’s duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining both common passageways and demised premises, and it abolishes the old rule that barred recovery for negligent maintenance of areas rented to the tenant. However, it does not specifically address entrance doors, locks, or a duty to keep common areas secure against crime; its focus is on physical safety from defective conditions (here, a porch railing). Thus, while it supports a general duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition, it does not provide authority for the more specific security-focused proposition.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 167\u2.relevant_excerpt: In the landlord-tenant field, we have held that a landlord is liable to a tenant’s guest for failing to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control without regard to their condition at the time of the letting. Lindsey v. Massios, supra. We said that “the status of the person visited, landowner or lessee, should not affect the visitor’s right to personal safety or the landowner’s obligation reasonably to maintain premises in his control.” Id. at 82. In King v. G & M Realty Corp., supra, we extended the landlord’s general and continuing duty to exercise reasonable care as to the safety of common passageways to include tenants as well as their visitors.

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 760–61 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover her actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and explains that a lessor who interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment is liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” The court rejects a multiplicative, per-month approach and clarifies that the statute sets a minimum of three months’ rent when actual and consequential damages are less, but otherwise the tenant recovers actual damages, plus costs and a reasonable attorney’s fee. This matches the stated proposition.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’ … Section 14 allows a minimum recovery of three months’ rent as an incentive to the pursuit of relief where the actual and consequential damages are slight or are difficult to prove. When the actual damages exceed three months’ rent, however, § 14 plainly states that actual damages should be the measure of recovery.”
